text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

During FY 13, the Appeals Account and Processing Support (APS) guidance was reorganized into existing APS IRM Sections IRM 8.20.5 Carding New Receipts , IRM 8.20.6 Interim Actions , and IRM 8.20.7 General Closing Procedures . This IRM 8.2.2 update reflects the removal of all APS guidance, and update or clarification of existing guidance for Appeals Technical Employees (ATEs).

IRM 8.2.2 is revised to remove Account and Processing Support (APS) guidance which was moved into IRM 8.20.5, Carding New Receipts, IRM 8.20.6, Interim Actions, and IRM 8.20.7 General Closing Procedures as a result of the FY 2013 APS IRM Reorganization Project.

Additional emphasis has been inserted to clarify that when a Statutory Notice of Deficiency is mailed to an address outside of the United States, the taxpayer has 150 days in which to file a petition with the tax court.
The term Appeals Officer (AO) has been replaced with the term Appeals Technical Employee
term Examination has been replaced with the term Compliance.

Additional emphasis has been incorporated into 8.2.2.2 require the Appeals Technical Employee confirms they’ve informed the taxpayer, that their deadline for petitioning the United States Tax Court (USTC) is neither suspended nor extended as a result of the Appeals consideration of the Compliance Issued Statutory Notice of Deficiency.

The Appeals Technical Employee responsibility for requesting an ACDS update has been clarified for any “Appeals Issued Statutory Notice of Deficiency” case sent to Counsel for Concurrence when the case is not routed through APS (8.2.2.3.1).

Guidance related to Undeliverable and Unclaimed SND’s has been updated and clarified since APS no longer has primary mail handling responsibilities for receiving and distributing incoming mail (8.2.2.3.2).
Cross-reference IRM citations have been added for all “APS-specific”
Reference to FSAA Letter has been removed since TEFRA no longer applies to “S Corporations”.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS IRM 8.2.2 dated August 7, 2012 is superseded.

rence must update ACDS with action code SNDC and the current date (date case sent to Counsel) to document the location of the administrative file.

) If the Appeals Team Manager (ATM) or Appeals Area Director decides to further consideration of a case during the suspense period, the ATE will: a. Request the administrative file be pulled from SND suspense and to the Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) b. APS will place a “Charge-Out” in the SND Suspense file in place of the administrative file. The “Charge-Out” will include the name of the case, ATE who requested the file be pulled, and the date the case was pulled and transmitted to the ATE. c. APS will also enter an alert in the Notes section of ACDS record that the case has been returned to the ATE for reconsideration. (

) If no agreement is reached after consideration or reconsideration in the suspense period the ATE will: a. Prepare an informal memorandum and a signed closing letter for the unagreed case. b. Secure the ATM signature and date the memorandum. c. Mail the closing letter. d. Associate the original memorandum and copy of the closing letter with administrative file. e. Return the administrative file to APS, using Form
transmittal. Internal Revenue Manual

a. Prepare an informal memorandum and a signed closing letter for the unagreed case. b. Secure the ATM signature and date the memorandum. c. Mail the closing letter. d. transmittal.

) Limitations regarding credits, refunds, and assessments relating to the rescinded notice are void and the rights and obligations of the parties that existed prior to the issuance of the statutory notice of deficiency are A statutory notice of deficiency may later be reissued for the same, or a greater or lesser, amount. (

) A taxpayer may exercise all administrative and statutory appeal rights from reissued statutory notice of deficiency. However, the taxpayer has no right file a petition with the Tax Court based on a rescinded notice. (
) The determination to rescind a statutory notice of deficiency should be on a case-by-case basis. Both parties must agree to the rescission. (
) A rescission will not be entered into if: a. It has been
days (
days for notices mailed to addresses outside United States) since the notice was issued. b. The taxpayer has petitioned the Tax Court. (
) If the statutory notice of deficiency was issued to both husband and wife, rescission agreement must be signed by both parties or authorized tive(s) for both parties. (
) The rescission agreement must cover all of the same tax periods shown in statutory notice of deficiency. (
) The rescission agreement must reflect the same tax deficiency and as the statutory notice of deficiency. (
) If the Service does not agree that a statutory notice of deficiency should be rescinded, the taxpayer will be notified in writing and the notice will remain effect. (
) All questions regarding the propriety of a rescission agreement on any case should be discussed with Counsel. (
) There are basically three reasons that a notice is rescinded. They are as follows: a. administrative error; b. incorrect or insufficient amount; c. an appeals conference is requested in a
-day case and no petition mailed or filed with Tax Court. (

) When an administrative error has occurred, the notice may be rescinded. following are examples of administrative errors: a. notice was issued to the wrong taxpayer; b. notice was issued for the wrong tax period; c. notice was prematurely issued due to failure of the Service to consider properly filed Form
, Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax. Internal Revenue Manual
Notice of Deficiency Cases 8.2.2
determination to rescind a statutory notice of deficiency should be a case-by-case basis. Both parties must agree to the rescission.
Pre
-Day and
-Day (

) If a statutory notice of deficiency has been issued for an incorrect or insuffi- cient amount, the notice may be rescinded. However, the taxpayer must be advised that another notice, for a greater amount, may be subsequently issued. (

) If a taxpayer specifically requests a conference with Appeals for the purpose entering into settlement negotiations, the notice may be rescinded. However, the notice will be rescinded only if Appeals is confident the case will result in an agreement. Appeals may request that the taxpayer submit, in writing, a protest or similar document that explains his or her position on the unagreed issues. See IRM
, Processing Docketed Cases, for further
-day case procedures. (
) If the normal three year period of limitations for assessment has expired do enter into an agreement to rescind the notice. for (
) If, on the date of rescission,
days or less remain before the expiration of period of limitation on assessment the notice may be rescinded but only if taxpayer and the Service execute a Form
to extend the limitation period. When determining how many days remain on the statute, do not consider additional time created by the issuance of the notice of deficiency. (
) Generally, a statutory notice of deficiency will not be rescinded if there is an outstanding Form
-A, Special Consent to Extend the Time to Assess Tax; however, see Rev. Proc.
C.B.
clarifying the Service’s position in situations where notice revocations may be considered. (
) Form
, Agreement to Rescind Notice of Deficiency, will be used to an agreement between the taxpayer and the Government. When preparing Agreement Form
, care must be exercised to ensure the accuracy of the Notice of contained within the document and its timely execution by both the taxpayer and the Government. (
) The rescission agreement form will be prepared in duplicate. Once executed, one copy of Form

will be secured to the return for the latest year by the agreement. The second copy will be sent to the taxpayer by mail or given to the taxpayer in person. Copies of the executed rescission will be attached to all other returns covered by that agreement. (
) One Form

may be used as a rescission agreement for all years contained in the rescinded notice of deficiency. All years covered by the agreement will be entered below the first paragraph under “Tax Year Ended.” The deficiencies and additions to tax, as shown on the notice of deficiency, be entered below the appropriate column headings. (
) The effective date for a rescission agreement is the date on which the Com- missioner or delegate signs the rescission form. (
) A taxpayer who believes that a statutory notice of deficiency should be rescinded because they wish to enter into settlement negotiations should contact Appeals and request Form

, Agreement to Rescind Notice of Deficiency, will be used to secure an agreement between the taxpayer and the Government. When preparing Form
, care must be exercised to ensure the accuracy of the information contained within the document and its timely execution by both the taxpayer and the Government. (
) The rescission agreement form will be prepared in duplicate. Once executed, one copy of Form

will be secured to the return for the latest year covered by the agreement. The second copy will be sent to the taxpayer by mail or given to the taxpayer in person. Copies of the executed rescission agreement will be attached to all other returns covered by that agreement. (
) One Form

may be used as a rescission agreement for all years contained in the rescinded notice of deficiency. All years covered by the agreement will be entered below the first paragraph under “Tax Year Ended.” The deficiencies and additions to tax, as shown on the notice of deficiency, will be entered below the appropriate column headings.
